titlestmt.titleproper: Social Science Research Council records, Near & Middle East, Record Group 3, Series 9
A Guide to the Social Science Research Council records, Near & Middle East, Record Group 3, Series 9 FA1777

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-10-01 04:56:32 UTC.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Social Science Research Council records, Near & Middle East, Record Group 3, Series 9

physdesc.extent: 77 boxes (62 letter document boxes, 14 legal document boxes, 1 half letter document box)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Social Science Research Council records, Near and Middle East, Record Group 3, Series 9 contains program materials related to committee meetings, administrative tasks, conferences, workshops, publications, research papers, awards, fellowships, and grants of the Joint Committee for Near and Middle East and the Joint Committee for the Comparative Study of Muslim Societies.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Social Science Research Council archives are arranged into three record groups distinguished by the date of their donation to the Archive Center. Accession 1 (Record Group 1) consists of the documents received by the Archive Center in 1990; Accession 2 (Record Group 2) was transferred to the Archive Center in 1994; Record Group 3 was transferred to the Archive Center in 2017-2018. Within series the records are primarily arranged in original order. Within Near and Middle East, Record Group 3, Series 9, there are two subseries: 1.) Joint Committee on the Near and Middle East, 1968-1996 and 2.) Joint Committee on the Comparative Study of Muslim Societies, 1984-1995.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The records in this series were received from the Social Science Research Council from 2017-2018.

did.unittitle: Joint Committee on the Near and Middle East

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In 1951, the Social Science Research Council established a committee to promote understanding of the contemporary Near and Middle East by developing social science materials and trained personnel in the field. In 1959, the Committee was reorganized as a joint committee of the Social Science Research Council and the American Council of Learned Societies. The Joint Committee on the Near and Middle East oversaw the Ibn Khaldun prize graduate student writing competition (beginning in 1984), led dissertation workshops, bestowed advanced research grants, organized conferences, produced publications, and awarded 38 dissertation fellowships over its lifetime. In 1996, the Social Science Research Council restructured its region-focused committees in response to changing scholarship priorities in the field of area studies. Funding for the committee's activities came from the Ford Foundation, the National Endowment for the Humanities, the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, and the William and Flora Hewlett Foundation. The Social Science Research Council itself is not a foundation, although it possesses a small sustaining fund. It does not depend on an endowment for its income, as do foundations; rather, it is a claimant agency to foundations for grants which have terms of one to five years.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Joint Committee on the Near and Middle East subseries contains committee meeting minutes and agendas, reviewed applications for advanced research grants for postdoctoral studies, reviewed applications for dissertation fellowships for predoctoral candidates, papers submitted to the Ibn Khaldun prize graduate student writing competition, correspondence related to the Near and Middle East Research Training Act (NMERTA), committee financial reports, grant proposals for committee funding, papers for conferences and committee publications, regional seminar materials, administrative correspondence, workshop materials, subcommittee and task force documents, and invitations to the Subcommittee on Law and Social Structure Summer Institute.

Joint Committee on the Comparative Study of Muslim Societies

physdesc.extent: 17 letter document boxes and 1 legal document box

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: From 1985-1993, the Joint Committee for the Comparative Study of Muslim Societies was active in encouraging interdisciplinary research into the relationship between Islamic systems of faith and knowledge in the social lives of Muslims. The basic mandate of the Committee was to help clarify the content, context, and linkages of Muslim nations and communities around the world. The Committee held dissertation workshops for graduate students, conducted a postdoctoral training and research grants program, and published books, including "Islam and the Political Economy of Meaning," "Muslim Travelers," and "Intellectuals and Militants." The Committee also focused on research projects such as "Movement and Change in Muslim Societies," "Being Muslim in a Non-Muslim Society," "Intellectuals and Militants in the Contemporary Muslim World," "The Making of a Fatwa," "Muslim Transnationalism," "Muslim Travelers," and "Vernacular Texts and Local Knowledge of Islam." The Ford Foundation provided the bulk of the funding for the committee with two grants beginning in 1985. The Committee was a joint committee of the Social Science Research Council and the American Council of Learned Societies. The Social Science Research Council itself is not a foundation, although it possesses a small sustaining fund. It does not depend on an endowment for its income, as do foundations; rather, it is a claimant agency to foundations for grants which have terms of one to five years.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Joint Committee for the Comparative Study of Muslim Societies subseries contains administrative correspondence related to organizing meetings, recruiting members, and obtaining grants, conference proposals and planning materials, research proposals, dissertation workshop invitations, and committee budgets.
